User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8.1) Gecko/20061010 Firefox/2.0
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8.1) Gecko/20061010 Firefox/2.0

When I open a file with a helper application, the dialog remembers the first helper I choose, and doesn't update if I use a different helper app later.

For example, if I open the first download link on the vim script site, and select /usr/bin/gvim to open it with, everything is fine.

The next time I click the link, I choose a different helper - /usr/bin/scite.  The dialog still says it is opening with /usr/bin/gvim, but if I press OK it does use /usr/bin/scite.  So it is doing the right thing, but not showing it.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Download a non-text/html file
2. Select a handler app
3. Download the file again
4. Select a different handler

Actual Results:  
The right thing happens, but the display leads one to believe that the wrong thing is going to happen.

Expected Results:  
The dialog should reflect the helper app I just picked.

Did this with a 10-minute old download of Firefox 2.0 RC3, and a completely empty profile.

comments.raw_text:
I just tested with Firefox 3.6.7, the Bug still exisits.

Steps to reproduce:
- Start with a fresh install of Windows XP SP3
- Find a mpeg file on the internet (I used http://www.pockettv.com/mpg/XPsmartTagsPPC.mpg)
- Download this file
- Download and install Firefox 3.6.7
- Download and install Zoomplayer (http://www.chip.de/downloads/Zoom-Player-Standard_13002205.html)
- Right click on the downloaded mpg file and set Zoomplayer as the default for mpg files
- If you doubleclick on the file, Zoomplayer should open
- Open Firefox, type the url of the mpg file into the url bar
- A dialog appears with the options to open the file. Select “Open With”. The combobox with programs should say “Windows Media Player (default)”. When you click “OK” the file opens in Zoomplayer.
